<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 220, 165, 236]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 278, 905, 292]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[731, 299, 905, 313]]<|/det|> February/March 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[763, 325, 905, 339]]<|/det|> 1 hour 50 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 391, 399]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 565, 496]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 544]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 591]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 75 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 714]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 74, 565, 91]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 269, 91]]<|/det|>
1 Solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 99, 581, 126]]<|/det|>
\[
\ln \left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 x}\right)+3=0
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 515, 153]]<|/det|>
Give your final answer correct to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 487, 98]]<|/det|>
2 The equation of a curve is \(x y^{2}+\ln \left(x+2 y\right)=1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 551, 127]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point where \(x=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
3

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 87, 727, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 386, 918, 404]]<|/det|>
The shaded region on the Argand diagram shows points representing complex numbers \(z\) defined by two inequalities. The shaded region is bounded by a circle and a line parallel to the real axis. The

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 418, 577, 435]]<|/det|>
boundaries of the region are included in the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 449, 659, 466]]<|/det|>
(a) Find two inequalities in terms of \(z\) that define the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 632, 576, 651]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the greatest value of \(|z|\) for points in this region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
4 By first expressing the equation \(\tan (x-60^{\circ})=2 \cot x\) as a quadratic equation in \(\tan x\), solve the equation for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
5 The square roots of \(-4+6 \sqrt{5} \mathrm{i}\) can be expressed in the Cartesian form \(x+\mathrm{i} y\), where \(x\) and \(y\) are real and exact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 918, 140]]<|/det|>
By first forming a quartic equation in \(x\) or \(y\), find the square roots of \(-4+6 \sqrt{5} \mathrm{i}\) in exact Cartesian form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 535, 91]]<|/det|>
6 The variables \(x\) and \(\theta\) satisfy the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[461, 97, 587, 128]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} \theta}=\left(\frac{1}{5} x+1\right) \sin ^{2} 2 \theta,
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 303, 153]]<|/det|>
and \(x=5\) when \(\theta=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 703, 184]]<|/det|>
Solve the differential equation and obtain an expression for \(x\) in terms of \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
7

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[315, 90, 682, 296]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 918, 327]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y=x^{3} \cos 2 x\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{4} \pi\). The curve has a maximum point at \(M\), where \(x=p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 349, 559, 382]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(p\) satisfies the equation \(p=\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{3}{2 p}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 472, 93]]<|/det|>
(b) Show by calculation that \(0.5<p<0.7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 919, 524]]<|/det|>
(c) Use an iterative formula based on the equation in part (a) to calculate \(p\) correct to 3 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 5 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 650, 134]]<|/det|>
8 Two lines have equations \(\mathbf{r}=\binom{-1}{3}+\lambda\left(\begin{array}{c}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right)\) and \(\mathbf{r}=\binom{2}{-3}+\mu\left(\begin{array}{c}-1 \\ 1\end{array}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 142, 385, 160]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that the lines are skew.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 634, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the obtuse angle between the directions of the two lines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
9 The polynomial \(6 x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+9\) is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) ，where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants．It is given that \((x-3)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) ，and when the first derivative \(\mathrm{p}^{\prime}(x)\) is divided by \((x-3)\) the remainder is 72 ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 366, 142]]<|/det|>
（a）Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 736, 93]]<|/det|>
(b) When \(a\) and \(b\) have the values found in part (a), factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 630, 449, 651]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence solve the inequality \(\mathrm{p}(x)<0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{2} \mathrm{f}(x) \mathrm{~d} x\). Give your answer in the form \(a \pi-\ln b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 424, 110]]<|/det|>
11 Find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\pi} x^{2} \cos\frac{1}{3} x \mathrm{~d} x\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
